person.name: Aretha Franklin
person.comments: But whatever she sang, she claimed it as her own. And as long as you live, you’ll never hear anything like Aretha Franklin. That’s why her voice still goes right on changing the world. — R.S.

person.name: Whitney Houston
person.comments: Houston’s self-titled 1985 debut came out a bit more than six months before her 22nd birthday, and it established her as one of pop’s most potent vocalists. — M.J.

person.name: Sam Cooke
person.comments: He was already a gospel superstar with the Soul Stirrers when he went solo in 1957 and immediately began defining the idea of “soul music” — J.G.

person.name: Billie Holiday
person.comments: “Billie Holiday makes you hear the content and intent of every word she sings — even at the expense of her pitch or tone,” Joni Mitchell once said. “Billie is the one that touches me deepest.” — H.S.

person.name: Mariah Carey
person.genre: Old-school soul and R&B with modern
person.comments: Carey birthed generations of imitators in her wake. But those she influenced still can’t beat the architect of modern pop’s sound. — B.S.

person.name: Ray Charles
person.genre: Titan of R&B, pop, jazz, and country
person.comments: And he turned one of the most anodyne of national hymns, “America the Beautiful,” into a soul-wrenching epic. The man could make anything soulful. — M.M.

person.name: Stevie Wonder
person.comments: “The thing about Stevie Wonder,” he said, “was that he brought these vocal mechanics into the squall that other motherfuckers just couldn’t do.” — H.S.

person.name: Otis Redding
person.comments: Onstage — start with his commanding performance at 1967’s Monterey Pop festival — Otis Redding was so boundless and revved up that he could literally make a stage shake. - D.B.

person.name: Al Green
person.comments: There’s something feline about Al Green’s voice — a sinuous flexibility that flares up in places the listener isn’t expecting, which is always welcome. Few singers create the illusion of being carried away by the very song they’re singing the way he can.
